title: Which faction in the Sudanese civil war will come out as the victor?

body.resolution_criteria:
The question will be resolved either when any of these conditions are met: - There is a **formal surrender** by either side, or a formal **long-term ceasefire/armistice** agreement.
- [CFR](https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/) **no longer lists** Sudan as in a state of civil war.
- The date is **April 15, 2033**, exactly 10 years after the war began.

When that occurs: - If one side has formally **disbanded, surrendered, or capitulated**, the other side is automatically considered the **victor**.
- If both sides still exist, and one side, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions), **controls the entirety of the capital area (defined as Khartoum, Omdurman, and Khartoum Bahri)**, then they are considered the **victor**.
If neither side has come out as the victor before April 15, 2033, then this resolves as **Another outcome**. Examples of such scenarios include but are not limited to: - A **continued stalemate**. If both sides still exist, and neither side has managed to completely drive the other side out of the capital area, then the the resolution is considered a stalemate. - Another entity such as another country takes control of Sudan. - Another Sudanese faction, distinct from the SAF and RSF, takes control. - United Nations, African Union, or other peacekeepers deployed to Sudan. - Sudan dissolving or splitting into new countries. - A SAF/RSF coalition government. - Any other unforeseen event that prevents resolution.
body.background_info:
On April 15, 2023, the two factions composing Sudan's military dictatorship, the **Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF)** and the **Rapid Support Forces (RSF)** went to war with each other over fears the the SAF was going to undermine the RSF's power.
As of May 2024, both sides control roughly half of Sudan, including half of the capital area (Khartoum, Omdurman, and Khartoum Bahri). Neither side appears to have an advantage over the other at the moment.
Further reading:
[The war's Wikipedia page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudanese_civil_war_(2023–present))
[r/Sudan post about the situation](https://www.reddit.com/r/Sudan/comments/18tszo5/please_read_war_in_sudan/)
[Center for Strategic & International Studies: Looking Ahead after a Year of Conflict in Sudan](https://www.csis.org/analysis/looking-ahead-after-year-conflict-sudan)

title: If Donald Trump wins the 2024 US presidential election, how many US Supreme Court Justices will have been appointed by him on January 21, 2029?

body.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as the number of Supreme Court Justices nominated by Donald Trump who have been confirmed by the Senate as of 00:00 Eastern on January 21, 2029. 

This is the total number of all such persons over time, not the number of serving or living Trump-appointed justices at that time.

If Donald Trump does not win the 2024 US presidential election, this question will be **annulled**.
body.background_info:
The [Supreme Court of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States?useskin=vector) (SCOTUS) is the highest court in the federal judiciary of the United States. The Court currently consists of nine justices, each having life tenure. Justices are nominated to the Court by the president, and their nominations either rejected or confirmed by the Senate. 

Of the nine [current justices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States?useskin=vector#Current_justices), six were appointed by Republican presidents, and three were appointed by Democratic presidents. As of July 2024, their tenures on the Court range from just over two years to nearly 33 years.

- Chief Justice John Roberts, born 1959, nominated by George W. Bush, serving since 2005

- Associate Justice Clarence Thomas, born 1948, nominated by George H. W. Bush, serving since 1991

- Associate Justice Samuel Alito, born 1950, nominated by George W. Bush, serving since 2006

- Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor, born 1954, nominated by Barack Obama, serving since 2009

- Associate Justice Elena Kagan, born 1960, nominated by Barack Obama, serving since 2010

- Associate Justice Neil Gorsuch, born 1967, nominated by Donald Trump, serving since 2017

- Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh, born 1965, nominated by Donald Trump, serving since 2018

- Associate Justice Amy Coney Barrett, born 1972, nominated by Donald Trump, serving since 2020

- Associate Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, born 1970, nominated by Joe Biden, serving since 2022


As Donald Trump is running for a second, non-consecutive term in the [2024 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election?useskin=vector), it is possible that he could nominate one or more additional jurists to serve on the Court. This presents the possibility that the Court's [current conservative majority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideological_leanings_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_justices?useskin=vector#Partisan_balance) could be preserved for decades to come; and that by recent standards, an unusually high proportion of justices on the Court would have been [nominated by a single president.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_judicial_appointments?useskin=vector) The last president to appoint more than three individuals to the Court was Richard Nixon, and the last to appoint more than four was Dwight Eisenhower.
